header.title: Redesigning Age | David Harry Stewart | TEDxAsburyPark
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: David Harry Stewart: Photographer, Founder and Face of AGEIST. . Increasing longevity is allowing people to work well past the official age of retirement, and those age 50+ are now a critically important demographic. Their political, social and economic standing makes them the most powerful generation to have ever lived. David suggests that our attitude towards later life needs a reboot at every level and that we have locked ourselves into a culture that is anti-age.   David is the founder of the media and research company AGEIST, whose purpose is to reinvent how life after 50 is lived.. Learn more at http://tedxasburypark.com/. . . It is well-documented that people over 50 are living in radically different ways than their parents, and those who are 50+ are now a critically important demographic. Their political, social and economic standing makes them the most powerful generation to have ever lived. David is the founder of media and research company AGEIST, whose purpose is to reinvent how life after 50 is lived, experienced, and understood. He says this is best achieved through design and modern media tactics rather than legislation, and until this is embraced, we will fail to see the real economic, humanitarian, and cultural benefits of increasing longevity.  David suggests that our attitude towards later life needs a reboot at every level. He says that we've locked ourselves into a culture that is anti-age and it is evident throughout media, organizations, and even in the language we use. 'Redesigning Age' It is well-documented that people over 50 are living in radically different ways than their parents, and those who are 50+ are now a critically important demographic. Their political, social and economic standing makes them the most powerful generation to have ever lived. David is founder of media and research company AGEIST, whose purpose is to reinvent how life after 50 is lived, experienced, and understood. He says this is best achieved through design and modern media tactics rather than legislation, and until this is embraced, we will fail to see the real economic, humanitarian, and cultural benefits of increasing longevity.  David suggests that our attitude towards later life needs a reboot at every level. He says that we've locked ourselves into a culture that is anti-age and it is evident throughout media, organizations, and even in the language we use. This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at https://www.ted.com/tedx

commentThread.commentText: Time has come for boomers to generate value and stewardship in their best years. I'm committed to maximizing our contribution.
Couldn't agree more with how people (I'm 64) are spoken to in advertising these days - I like to say - We love a Harley and a really nice leather jacket  not Bingo at the Rec Center.
Great job, David! I completely redefined my career after 50 to create my "next act" and I'm loving it.

replies.commentText: Awesome Larry! That takes guts, but shows that we can change what is not working for us.

commentThread.commentText: Such a thrill to be up on that stage! Highlight of a lifetime. Thank you TEDx AsburyPark for your mentoring and support. Great team there and I am so happy to have been part of the event.

replies.commentText: Wish I had known you were here! Now I have to fly to LAX for the first YBL conference!🤣

commentThread.commentText: Resonant video that captures the zeitgeist of this incredible time of being alive in the second half of life.  Bravo.
Good job!  You spoke with passion and surety, David. Worth our time to continue to think about.

People are Changing their lives at any age now. In the past 20 years with the failing economic climate people became less mobile in a sense moving or traveling to other places and living differently or changing their quality of life decreased in my opinion.

replies.commentText: Good point, makes sense that economics and mobility are linked.

AGEIST   I mean if im in an area where meeting a great person is my goal but that just isnt here and the finances wont allow me to move to where there are better # s then it looks as if im stuck or selectively single.  It does make sense about the Chattanooga TN area....

commentThread.commentText: love it! strong people are hard to kill!

replies.commentText: Ha! You have seen our tote bags. Yes, stay strong, live long!

commentThread.commentText: Love this, so inspiring, thank you!
Great job! I am 64 and going strong!

replies.commentText: Thank you! 64 is a great age, lets keep pushing ahead.
